docs.lead_paragraph: A decade ago, corporate America tore up the social contract that bound employees to their companies. Downsizing and re-engineering made it clear that employees were expendable commodities, not valued resources. Today, many bright workers are getting their revenge by fleeing their fickle employers for better-paying rivals -- or dot-com start-ups. Indeed, quitting has become so fashionable in Silicon Valley that the turnover rate for companies there has reached an estimated 25 percent a year. The average American 32-year-old has already worked for nine different companies. Workers today fantasize not about landing a ''dream job'' but about having a ''portfolio career'' -- one dream job after the other.
docs.abstract: Adrian Wooldridge article says American corporations destroyed employee loyalty a decade ago, when downsizing and re-engineering made it clear that employees were expendable commodities, and corporations are paying the price today as workers think nothing of leaving one employer for another that pays more; three leading management experts, Jeffrey Pfeffer, Rosabeth Moss Kanter and Tom Peters, comment on whether and how employers can regain loyalty of their workers; drawing (L)
docs.snippet: A decade ago, corporate America tore up the social contract that bound employees to their companies. Downsizing and re-engineering made it clear that employees were expendable commodities, not valued resources. Today, many bright workers are getting...

docs.lead_paragraph: It's early winter. Cold. We've ordered in breaded-chicken sandwiches, Ari Horowitz and I, and are sitting in his cheerless office in Midtown Manhattan. ''This whole concept of having to be in the office from 9 to 5, or whatever it is, that's gone, that's just not the world,'' muses Horowitz, founder of FreeAgent.com, a Web site for independent contractors, freelancers, part-timers and moonlighters. ''There's no corporate loyalty or any of that stuff anymore.'' Above Horowitz's desk is a badly framed reproduction of a Jackson Pollock. Near the door, tacked to the wall, is a blown-up cover of Snowboard Life magazine that Horowitz rescued from someone's trash. (''Learn to Snowboard the Easy Way!'') Not that Horowitz, 31, has much time for snowboarding or art collecting. Himself, he's not a free agent. ''I'm an entrepreneur, so I've got to come here every day. I can't disappear. I can't even take vacations. The free agent has a much better lifestyle. They're not necessarily going to make as much money as I might, but they can go snowboarding; they can decide when they want to work and when they don't want to work. It's an incredible lifestyle. I can't really think of a better way to spend your life.''
docs.abstract: Nina Munk article on the much-hyped allure of working as a free agent, liberated from rules and schedules of corporate America, and the high price most free agents pay for that liberation; says that while free agency may be great for people whose skills are in high demand, 60 percent of free agents earn less than regular full-time workers in comparable jobs and do not have dental plans, expense accounts, life insurance, 401(k) plans, sick leave, stock options, paid vacations or protection of employment laws; says nearly all the people she contacted through FreeAgent.com admit that if the right full-time, permanent job came along, they would embrace it eagerly; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: After a three-month debate with employers over whether they would be allowed to vote on unionization, handymen, porters and superintendents employed by the Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corporation voted 32 to 9 last week to become part of Teamsters Local 966. The vote came one month after the National Labor Relations Board's regional director in Brooklyn ordered the corporation, which develops housing for the poor, to allow the workers to hold a vote. The vote affects employees at 11 of the corporation's buildings; a 12th was already unionized.

headline.main: After 3-Month Struggle, Housing Workers Join Teamsters

docs.abstract: Building workers employed by Bedford-Stuyvesant Restoration Corp vote to join Teamsters (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: By their media shall ye know them. That has always been my test for whole societies. Never mind whether they call themselves Democracy or Republic: free press means free country; controlled press, miserable tyranny. The same goes for individuals. My media test also works for sorting out people, especially office workers. Never mind the title on the door or the workplace habitat, media power is what denotes true rank, clout and worth.

headline.main: The Way We Work Now: 3-5-00: Word & Image; Free Agents Unite!

docs.abstract: Max Frankel column says independent contractors, free agents and self-owned businesses operating from home over the Internet may have more freedom and flexibility than communal office workers, but those advantages are more than outweighed by the corporate perks they are denied, including group health and pension plans subsidized by taxpayers as well as employers, numerous workplace amenities and unemployment insurance; predicts that most free agents will eventually join unions that bargain for benefits and provided shared services (M)
docs.snippet: By their media shall ye know them.    That has always been my test for whole societies. Never mind whether they call themselves Democracy or Republic: free press means free country; controlled press, miserable tyranny. The same goes for individuals....

docs.lead_paragraph: Like trapeze artists, the Republican governors catch George W. Bush as he flies into their states and swing him through the air, trying to get him to the platform safely. They supply the machines and muscle and brass-knuckle strategists and line of attack for those blistering ads. They remold W. into whatever will work for their states.
docs.abstract: Maureen Dowd Op-Ed column on how Republican governors are remolding their favorite presidential aspirant, George W Bush, into whatever will work with voters in their states; describes latest example, Georege Pataki dangling his old Yale classmate to take up, for first time, cause of breast cancer in front of concerned New Yorkers (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: The Odyssey Diner here is one of those old-fashioned political hangouts, where establishment pols, mostly Republicans, gather at the counter or in a side room to hash things out over the famous cheesecake and coffee courtesy of the affable Doukases, who have run the place for 27 years. But the stiff competition among the G.O.P. candidates and the approach of the New York primary on Tuesday have enlivened the discourse here, even among the Doukas family. They unwittingly served up an example of the split among Republican voters in this 336-year-old town of mansions and Cape Cod-style homes when it comes to George W. Bush and John McCain.

headline.main: G.O.P. Race Challenges Loyalties, and Families

docs.abstract: Interviews with Republican voters in Eastchester indicate that they are split over whether to support Gov George W Bush or Sen John McCain in upcoming New York State primary; photos (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Investors bought up shares of Aetna Inc. again yesterday, but the buying spree slowed as it became apparent that rival bidders were unlikely to emerge to challenge the $9.9 billion offer announced this week by Aetna. Aetna said it had received the offer from ING America Insurance Holdings, a financial services company, and WellPoint Health Networks, a California-based national managed care company.

headline.main: Other Bids for Aetna Unlikely, Analysts Say

docs.abstract: Rival bidders are unlikely to emerge to challenge $9.9 billion offer announced by Aetna Inc; Aetna says it received offer from ING America Insurance Holdings and WellPoint Health Networks; graph (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Negotiators from the House and the Senate, meeting for the first time, said today that they were optimistic about their chances of cutting a deal on legislation that would establish a wide range of new rights for patients and new duties for health insurance companies. President Clinton urged members of the conference committee to reach a bipartisan agreement. And Senator Don Nickles of Oklahoma, the assistant Republican leader, said he hoped to do just that by the end of this month.

headline.main: Negotiations Begin on a Health Care Bill

docs.lead_paragraph: Shares of Palm Pilot Maker Soar on First Day of Trading Continuing a wave of enthusiasm for companies involved in the Internet and wireless communications, investors snapped up shares of Palm, the maker of the Palm Pilot handheld devices. The shares traded as high as $165, more than four times the offering price of $38, before retreating to slightly more than $95. At that price, the market is valuing Palm at $53.3 billion, far more than the value of its parent, 3Com, which still owns most of the company. Palm's market value is higher than that of many far larger companies, including Ford, General Motors and Chevron. [Page A1.] Inquiry Clouds Sotheby's Report Sotheby's Holdings could do little to dispel investors' concerns over the outcome of a federal antitrust investigation as it discussed its Internet prospects and posted better-than-expected fourth-quarter results. While William F. Ruprecht, the company's new chief executive, spoke optimistically about Sotheby's future in holding auctions over the Internet, he acknowledged fierce competition and the challenges of proceeding in the face of an investigation and the threat to its reputation. Last week, the company's chairman, A. Alfred Taubman, and its president and chief executive, Diana D. Brooks, abruptly resigned as the company and its archrival, Christie's, were accused of colluding to fix commissions. [C2.]
docs.snippet: Shares of Palm Pilot Maker Soar on First Day of Trading  Continuing a wave of enthusiasm for companies involved in the Internet and wireless communications, investors snapped up shares of Palm, the maker of the Palm Pilot handheld devices. The shares...

docs.lead_paragraph: New York City shoppers found bargains yesterday in sweaters, slacks, leotards, lab coats and other garments as the 8.25 percent combined city and state sales tax was eliminated for nearly all clothing and shoes at $110 or less -- this time, for good. The tax cut will cost the city $237 million in revenue in the coming fiscal year, Department of Finance officials have estimated. But Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani, who has made sales tax relief a priority for the past four years, predicted the repeal would discourage New York shoppers from crossing the Hudson River to avoid the tax and the resulting spike in sales would ultimately lead to thousands of new jobs.

headline.main: Sales Tax Is Lifted on Clothing Under $110

docs.abstract: New York City lifts 8.25 percent sales tax on all clothing and shoes that cost under $110; tax cut will cost city $237 million in revenue in coming fiscal year (M)
